text: Okay, so a common critique and valid point that people often bring up about Bayesian statistics is, well, don't you just get out what you put in?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Like if your prior is such and such, then don't you just recover your prior in the posterior?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And there's multiple ways to address that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One of them is
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you start with multiple different priors, so from the same family, parameterized differently, or from different families, and you recover your prior, then you actually can empirically say that there isn't information in your data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But to the extent that those diverse priors converge on a similar posterior, you can empirically say that there is signal in the data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's not binary, but those are different heuristics that are used.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So one approach to kind of get around or to address this reviewer type comment that like, oh, well, Bayesian statistics just returns your priors is to try different priors.

text: And there's also another approach, which is called parametric empirical Bayes.

text: So it's called empirical because we're taking empirical data and using that to initiate the cycle of optimization.
